title: Technical details for bdlim
text: implementation BDLIM package slightly different model described original paper. model updated based experiance applying model variety datasets user feedback. describe model .

title: Technical details for bdlim
text: BDLIM model Gaussian regression continuous outcome \[y_i = \alpha_{j_i} + \beta_{j_i}\int_\mathcal{T} x_{}(t) \omega_{j_i}(t) dt + \mathbf{z}_i'\boldsymbol\gamma + \varepsilon_{}.\] model: \(j_i\) denotes group observation \(\) belongs . \(\) indexes individual observation. \(y_i\) scalar response. \(\alpha_{j_i}\) fixed intercept group \(j_i\) \(x_{}(t)\) exposure individual \(\) time \(t\) considered functional predictor model. \(\omega_{j_i}(t)\) weight function observations group \(j_i\). weight function constrained \(\int_\mathcal{T} \omega_{j_i}(t) dt \ge 0\) \(\int_\mathcal{T} [\omega_{j_i}(t)]^2 dt=1\) \(\mathbf{z}'\) vector covariates. \(\boldsymbol\gamma\) regression coefficients covariates. \(\varepsilon_i\) residual error Gaussian model assumed independent normal mean 0 variance \(\sigma^2\).

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: package can installed GitHub command:
code: remotes::install_github("anderwilson/bdlim") # load package library(bdlim) #> This is bdlim 0.2.1. #> For details: help(`bdlim-package`), vignette('bdlim'), or https://anderwilson.github.io/bdlim/

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: code chunk fits model. comparison examples, uses large number iterations (20000). See comments convergence choosing number iterations. iterations takes longer. can partially offset using parallel computing. BDLIM fits compares 4 models. Setting parallel=TRUE run four models parallel. reduces computation time 2-4 fold. least 4 cores computer (almost certainly ) advised use parallel computing. return object class bdlim4 contains posterior sample four models.
code: # set seed so we get same results when rerunning set.seed(316)  # fit model fit_sex <- bdlim4(   y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz,   exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,paste0("pm25_",1:37)],   covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,c("MomPriorBMI","MomAge","race","Hispanic",                                    "EstMonthConcept","EstYearConcept")],   group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),   df = 5,   nits = 20000,   nthin = 1,   parallel = FALSE ) #> fitting bw #> fitting b #> fitting w #> fitting n #> postprocessingpostprocessing

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: Next step view results. First, can compare model fits four patterns modification. case BDLIM-bw model, model different effect sizes weight functions group, highest posterior model probabilities. use model primary model. Next, summary allows us view model output make calculations needed view plots. summary function automatically reports results best fitting model (BDLIM-bw case). key elements summary function : model fit statistics: posterior model probabilities WAIC. Posterior model probabilities used determine pattern modification best supported data. WAIC used compare hyperparameters, mainly df used spline basis. posterior summary cumulative effect: posterior mean, standard deviation, credible intervals provided group. provided even group differences. posterior summary covariate regression coefficients: posterior mean, standard deviation, credible intervals provided regression coefficients covariates group-specific intercepts. Finally, can plot results. plots show estimated distributed lag function group. interpreted effect one unit change exposure single time point holding everything else constant.
code: fit_sex #>  #> Call: #> bdlim4(y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz, exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     paste0("pm25_", 1:37)], covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     c("MomPriorBMI", "MomAge", "race", "Hispanic", "EstMonthConcept",  #>         "EstYearConcept")], group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),  #>     df = 5, nits = 20000, nthin = 1, parallel = FALSE) #>  #> Modification pattern probabilities (higher is better fit): #>   *bw*      b      w      n  #> 0.5241 0.4757 0.0002 0.0000  #>  #> Modification pattern WAIC (lower is better fit): #>        bw      *b*        w        n #> 1 1698.36 1698.278 1727.316 1735.125 #>  #> Note: Model probabilities tend to favor more complex models compared to WAIC. It is recomended to use model probabilities for selecting the modification pattern and WAIC to compare degrees of freedom for the weight function. sfit_sex <- summary(fit_sex) sfit_sex #>  #> Call: #> bdlim4(y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz, exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     paste0("pm25_", 1:37)], covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     c("MomPriorBMI", "MomAge", "race", "Hispanic", "EstMonthConcept",  #>         "EstYearConcept")], group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),  #>     df = 5, nits = 20000, nthin = 1, parallel = FALSE) #>  #>  #> Model fit statistics: #>   *bw*      b      w      n  #> 0.5241 0.4757 0.0002 0.0000  #>  #>  #> Estimated cumulative effects: #>  group        mean       median         sd        q2.5      q97.5 pr_gr0 #>      F  0.01265607  0.003955644 0.05747093 -0.09589774  0.1477296 0.5768 #>      M -0.64229013 -0.640135385 0.09668678 -0.83429787 -0.4595210 0.0000 #>  #>  #> Estimated covariate regression coefficients: #>                   name         mean       median          sd          q2.5 #>  interceptnames_groups -1.288649009 -1.352794065 6.329812351 -13.770184970 #>  interceptnames_groups  0.278686005  0.217242365 6.335975467 -12.250935583 #>            MomPriorBMI -0.054166358 -0.054192685 0.003145915  -0.060347975 #>                 MomAge -0.001608893 -0.001591128 0.003126360  -0.007893414 #>            raceAsianPI  0.156088428  0.155867977 0.237822858  -0.315056574 #>              raceBlack  0.038428563  0.037625608 0.241294642  -0.428910476 #>              racewhite  0.103999310  0.104812728 0.231502812  -0.351104997 #>    HispanicNonHispanic  0.254167520  0.253542346 0.039506057   0.175608920 #>        EstMonthConcept  0.036834221  0.036780395 0.005499963   0.026110036 #>         EstYearConcept  0.001589746  0.001617969 0.003141937  -0.004611998 #>         q97.5 pr_gr0 #>  11.234639550 0.4168 #>  12.740740315 0.5139 #>  -0.047987580 0.0000 #>   0.004489367 0.3044 #>   0.624049796 0.7460 #>   0.514582108 0.5636 #>   0.557782646 0.6737 #>   0.331154266 1.0000 #>   0.047773498 1.0000 #>   0.007734955 0.6923 #>  #>  #> BDLIM fit on 1000 observations. Estimated residual standard deviation is 0.562 (0.538,0.588). WAIC is 1698.36. #>  #> Use `plot(); for the summary.bdlim4 object to view estimated distributed lag functions. The `dlfun' object in the summary object contains estimates of the lag functions. plot(sfit_sex)

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: Valid inference requires sufficient posterior sample. three parameters control MCMC: nits number iterations large (20000 - 100000). nburn number iterations discarded burn . set half total number iterations. can generally left unspecified unless. nthin thinning factor. sampler keep every niter iterations nburn niter. Ideally, like decently large posterior sample (e.g. 2000-10000). Therefore, want (nits-nburn)/nthin equal something range.

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: check convergence, advised run model times different seeds. , compare results change. results similar likely model converged. different, increase number iterations.

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: Trace plots can made posterior. example, trace plot BDLIM-bw model 2 times distributed lag function first group can made shown .   MCMC diagnostics can performed directly using posterior sample illustrated trace plot.
code: plot(fit_sex$fit_bw$dlfun[[1]][,10], type="l", las=1) plot(fit_sex$fit_bw$dlfun[[1]][,25], type="l", las=1)

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: weight function uses orthonormal version natural spline. number degrees freedom must selected df. Generally, degrees freedom 3, 4, 5, 6. select degrees freedom, consider fitting models choices. compare WAIC models (provided summary). lower WAIC indicates better model fit. Also visually compare distributed lag function estimates.

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: graphs provided plot function unlikely sufficient publications presentations. minimum, axis labels specific enough. two ways improve graphs. first way make minor edits graph ggplot2. example , plot saved object plt. , title better y-axis label added.  second option make entirely new plot posterior estimate obtained summary function.
code: library(ggplot2)  # save plot plt <- plot(sfit_sex)  # edit plot plt <- plt + ggtitle("My plot with BDLIM") +   ylab("Estimated expected difference in\nBWGAZ per 1 ug/m3 increase in exposure")  # display new plot plt ggplot(sfit_sex$dlfun, aes(x=time, y=mean, ymin=q2.5, ymax=q97.5, color=group, fill=group)) +   geom_ribbon(color=NA, alpha=.6) + geom_line() +   theme_light() +   ggtitle("My plot with BDLIM") +   ylab("Estimated expected difference in\nBWGAZ per 1 ug/m3 increase in exposure") +    xlab("Gestational age (exposure time)")

title: Example analysis with bdlim on simulated data
text: random intercept can included model longitudinal studies groupings. id option vector factor variables. results returned object summarized summary function.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ander Wilson. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Wilson (2024). bdlim: Bayesian Distributed Lag Interaction Models. R package version 0.2.1, https://anderwilson.github.io/bdlim/. Wilson , Chiu YM, Hsu HL, Wright RO, Wright RJ, Coull BA (2017). “Bayesian distributed lag interaction models identify perinatal windows vulnerability children's health.” Biostatistics, 18(3), 537–552. doi:10.1093/biostatistics/kxx002.
code: @Manual{,   title = {bdlim: Bayesian Distributed Lag Interaction Models},   author = {Ander Wilson},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.2.1},   url = {https://anderwilson.github.io/bdlim/}, } @Article{,   title = {Bayesian distributed lag interaction models to identify perinatal windows of vulnerability in children's health},   author = {Ander Wilson and Yueh-Hsiu Mathilda Chiu and Hsiao-Hsien Leon Hsu and Robert O. Wright and Rosalind J. Wright and Brent A. Coull},   journal = {Biostatistics},   year = {2017},   volume = {18},   number = {3},   pages = {537–552},   doi = {10.1093/biostatistics/kxx002}, }

title: Bayesian Distributed Lag Interaction Models
text: bdlim R package implements Bayesian distributed lag interaction models (BDLIMs). developmental package replace code regimes. currently testing package building additional functionality. Background model can found : Wilson , Chiu YM, Hsu HL, Wright RO, Wright RJ, Coull BA (2017). “Bayesian distributed lag interaction models identify perinatal windows vulnerability children’s health.” Biostatistics, 18(3), 537–552. (DOI: 10.1093/biostatistics/kxx002, arXiv preprint) short, BDLIM estimated distributed lag model (DLM) modification single categorical variable. categorical variable can binary two levels, BDLIM advised large number categories. instead interested DLM modification single continuous variable see dlim package. interested distributed lag models heterogeneity multiple modifiers see heterogeneous distributed lag model dlmtree package. package includes several improvements previous software. Many improvements come user feedback experiance applying BDLIM multiple datasets. include: Simpler syntax Updated options longer recommended hyperparameter settings longer available Faster options parallel implementation Summary plot functions provide intuative results.

title: Bayesian Distributed Lag Interaction Models
text: Install GitHub using code . want build vignette, use devtools::install(build_vignettes = TRUE) option. Building vignette take couple minutes. Alternatively, can use online version available anderwilson.github.io/bdlim/articles/bdlim.html.
code: remotes::install_github("anderwilson/bdlim", devtools::install(build_vignettes = TRUE))

title: Bayesian Distributed Lag Interaction Models
text: vignette can accessed following code accessed anderwilson.github.io/bdlim/articles/bdlim.html. main function bdlim4. See help file function detailed example. summary plot functions can used make inference results. Specifically: model probabilities summary indicate pattern heterogeneity best supported data. Cumulative effect estimates provided summary function output. plot function show estimated distributed lag functions group. returns ggplot object can modified. See help file example plot.summary.bdlim4 example modifies plot. Estimates distributed lag functions available summary object printed console. See help file summary.bdlim4 example. example use parallel implementation. 4 cores available (computers ), try using parallel=TRUE option.
code: library(bdlim) vignette("bdlim")

what: bdlim: Bayesian Distributed Lag Interaction Models — bdlim-package
title: bdlim: Bayesian Distributed Lag Interaction Models — bdlim-package
text: Code fitting interpreting Bayesian distributed lag interaction models (BDLIMs). BDLIM regresses scalar outcome repeated measures exposure allows modification categorical variable four specific patterns modification. main function bdlim(). also summary plotting files. Details methodology described Wilson et al. (2017) <10.1093/biostatistics/kxx002>.

title: bdlim: Bayesian Distributed Lag Interaction Models — bdlim-package
text: Maintainer: Ander Wilson ander.wilson@colostate.edu (ORCID)

what: Fit the BDLIM model with 1 pattern of modification — bdlim1
title: Fit the BDLIM model with 1 pattern of modification — bdlim1
text: Fit BDLIM model 1 pattern modification

title: Fit the BDLIM model with 1 pattern of modification — bdlim1
code: bdlim1(   y,   exposure,   covars,   group,   id = NULL,   w_free,   b_free,   df,   nits,   nburn = round(nits/2),   nthin = 1 )

title: Fit the BDLIM model with 1 pattern of modification — bdlim1
text: y vector outcomes exposure matrix exposures one row individual covars matrix data.frame covariates include grouping factor (see group ). may include factor variables. group vector group memberships. factor variable. id optional vector individual IDs repeated measures groupings random intercept included . must factor variable. w_free Logical indicating weight functions shared groups (FALSE) group-specific (TRUE). b_free Logical indicating effect sizes shared groups (FALSE) group-specific (TRUE). df Degrees freedom weight functions nits Number MCMC iterations. nburn Number MCMC iterations discarded burn . default half MCMC iterations. used WAIC function passed summary plot functions used . nthin Thinning factors MCMC. used WAIC function passed summary plot functions used .

title: Fit the BDLIM model with 1 pattern of modification — bdlim1
text: list posteriors parameters

what: Fit the BDLIM model with all 4 patterns of modification — bdlim4
title: Fit the BDLIM model with all 4 patterns of modification — bdlim4
text: Fit BDLIM model 4 patterns modification

title: Fit the BDLIM model with all 4 patterns of modification — bdlim4
code: bdlim4(   y,   exposure,   covars,   group,   id = NULL,   df,   nits,   nburn = round(nits/2),   nthin = 1,   parallel = TRUE )

title: Fit the BDLIM model with all 4 patterns of modification — bdlim4
text: y vector outcomes exposure matrix exposures one row individual covars matrix data.frame covariates include grouping factor (see group ). may include factor variables. group vector group memberships. factor variable. id optional vector individual IDs repeated measures groupings random intercept included . must factor variable. df Degrees freedom weight functions nits Number MCMC iterations. nburn Number MCMC iterations discarded burn . default half MCMC iterations. used WAIC function passed summary plot functions used . nthin Thinning factors MCMC. used WAIC function passed summary plot functions used . parallel Logical use parallel computing 4 models. TRUE min 4 number cores available used.

title: Fit the BDLIM model with all 4 patterns of modification — bdlim4
text: list results different pattern modification model compassion metrics

title: Fit the BDLIM model with all 4 patterns of modification — bdlim4
code: # run BDLIM with modification by ChildSex fit_sex <- bdlim4(   y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz,   exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,paste0("pm25_",1:37)],   covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,c("MomPriorBMI","MomAge","race","Hispanic",                                    "EstMonthConcept","EstYearConcept")],   group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),   id = as.factor(rep(1:100,10)),   df = 5,   nits = 5000,   parallel = FALSE ) #> fitting bw #> fitting b #> fitting w #> fitting n #> postprocessingpostprocessing  # show model comparison results fit_sex #>  #> Call: #> bdlim4(y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz, exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     paste0("pm25_", 1:37)], covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     c("MomPriorBMI", "MomAge", "race", "Hispanic", "EstMonthConcept",  #>         "EstYearConcept")], group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),  #>     id = as.factor(rep(1:100, 10)), df = 5, nits = 5000, parallel = FALSE) #>  #> Modification pattern probabilities (higher is better fit): #>     bw      b      w    *n*  #> 0.0220 0.0228 0.2532 0.7020  #>  #> Modification pattern WAIC (lower is better fit): #>         bw        b        w      *n* #> 1 1752.416 1753.077 1736.249 1726.012 #>  #> Note: Model probabilities tend to favor more complex models compared to WAIC. It is recomended to use model probabilities for selecting the modification pattern and WAIC to compare degrees of freedom for the weight function.  #summarize results sfit_sex <- summary(fit_sex) sfit_sex #>  #> Call: #> bdlim4(y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz, exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     paste0("pm25_", 1:37)], covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     c("MomPriorBMI", "MomAge", "race", "Hispanic", "EstMonthConcept",  #>         "EstYearConcept")], group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),  #>     id = as.factor(rep(1:100, 10)), df = 5, nits = 5000, parallel = FALSE) #>  #>  #> Model fit statistics: #>     bw      b      w    *n*  #> 0.0220 0.0228 0.2532 0.7020  #>  #>  #> Estimated cumulative effects: #>  group       mean     median         sd       q2.5      q97.5 pr_gr0 #>      F -0.3114493 -0.3087748 0.06389747 -0.4377542 -0.1935044      0 #>      M -0.3114493 -0.3087748 0.06389747 -0.4377542 -0.1935044      0 #>  #>  #> Estimated covariate regression coefficients: #>                 name          mean        median          sd          q2.5 #>               groupF  0.3019720349  0.2540055213 6.201140939 -11.515936766 #>               groupM -1.8765903124 -1.9463339900 6.201301069 -13.711795784 #>          MomPriorBMI -0.0546532669 -0.0546725062 0.003212594  -0.061033981 #>               MomAge  0.0002328821  0.0002437104 0.003199824  -0.006058641 #>          raceAsianPI  0.1738110681  0.1721560875 0.241326353  -0.302785327 #>            raceBlack  0.0221676313  0.0237934785 0.242759545  -0.456197007 #>            racewhite  0.0943480388  0.0936538827 0.234244835  -0.364148562 #>  HispanicNonHispanic  0.2569435277  0.2572861475 0.039693701   0.175984482 #>      EstMonthConcept  0.0364333700  0.0363541507 0.005821169   0.025040452 #>       EstYearConcept  0.0017098137  0.0017772571 0.003082969  -0.004485397 #>         q97.5 pr_gr0 #>  12.708431305 0.5160 #>  10.535830234 0.3800 #>  -0.048546073 0.0000 #>   0.006526870 0.5328 #>   0.628968663 0.7728 #>   0.483471288 0.5428 #>   0.538878304 0.6572 #>   0.333047222 1.0000 #>   0.047881802 1.0000 #>   0.007615868 0.7084 #>  #>  #> BDLIM fit on 1000 observations. Estimated residual standard deviation is 0.553 (0.529,0.579). Estimated random effect standard deviation is 0.215 (0.177,0.256) with 100 levels. WAIC is 1726.012. #>  #> Use `plot(); for the summary.bdlim4 object to view estimated distributed lag functions. The `dlfun' object in the summary object contains estimates of the lag functions. # graph the estimated distributed lag functions for each group plot(sfit_sex)     # run BDLIM with modification by Hispanic fit_hisp <- bdlim4(   y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz,   exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,paste0("pm25_",1:37)],   covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,c("MomPriorBMI","MomAge","race","ChildSex",                                       "EstMonthConcept","EstYearConcept")],   group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$Hispanic),   df = 5,   nits = 5000,   parallel = FALSE ) #> fitting bw #> fitting b #> fitting w #> fitting n #> postprocessingpostprocessing  # show model comparison results fit_hisp #>  #> Call: #> bdlim4(y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz, exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     paste0("pm25_", 1:37)], covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     c("MomPriorBMI", "MomAge", "race", "ChildSex", "EstMonthConcept",  #>         "EstYearConcept")], group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$Hispanic),  #>     df = 5, nits = 5000, parallel = FALSE) #>  #> Modification pattern probabilities (higher is better fit): #>     bw    *b*      w      n  #> 0.3656 0.6112 0.0168 0.0064  #>  #> Modification pattern WAIC (lower is better fit): #>         bw      *b*       w        n #> 1 1726.404 1722.482 1737.86 1735.784 #>  #> Note: Model probabilities tend to favor more complex models compared to WAIC. It is recomended to use model probabilities for selecting the modification pattern and WAIC to compare degrees of freedom for the weight function.  # summarize results for best fitting pattern of modification sfit_hisp <- summary(fit_hisp)  # graph the estimated distributed lag functions for each group plot(sfit_hisp)   # summarize and force results from model with # subgroup-specific effects and weights sfit_hisp_bw <- summary(fit_hisp, model="bw") plot(sfit_hisp_bw)

what: Make orthonomal basis for weight functions — makebasis

title: Make orthonomal basis for weight functions — makebasis
code: makebasis(exposure, df)

title: Make orthonomal basis for weight functions — makebasis
text: exposure Matrix repeated measures exposure n x T n number observations T number time points. df Degrees freedom (including intercept) natural spline basis used.

title: Make orthonomal basis for weight functions — makebasis
text: matrix orthonormal basis expansions exposure time. matrix T x df. span natural splines intercept df degrees freedom.

title: Make orthonomal basis for weight functions — makebasis

title: Plot for Summary pf BDLIM — plot.summary.bdlim4
code: # run BDLIM with modification by ChildSex fit_sex <- bdlim4(   y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz,   exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,paste0("pm25_",1:37)],   covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,c("MomPriorBMI","MomAge","race","Hispanic",                                       "EstMonthConcept","EstYearConcept")],   group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),   df = 5,   nits = 5000,   parallel = FALSE ) #> fitting bw #> fitting b #> fitting w #> fitting n #> postprocessingpostprocessing  # show model comparison results fit_sex #>  #> Call: #> bdlim4(y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz, exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     paste0("pm25_", 1:37)], covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     c("MomPriorBMI", "MomAge", "race", "Hispanic", "EstMonthConcept",  #>         "EstYearConcept")], group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),  #>     df = 5, nits = 5000, parallel = FALSE) #>  #> Modification pattern probabilities (higher is better fit): #>   *bw*      b      w      n  #> 0.5684 0.4316 0.0000 0.0000  #>  #> Modification pattern WAIC (lower is better fit): #>       *bw*       b        w        n #> 1 1698.558 1700.12 1727.196 1736.152 #>  #> Note: Model probabilities tend to favor more complex models compared to WAIC. It is recomended to use model probabilities for selecting the modification pattern and WAIC to compare degrees of freedom for the weight function.  #summarize results sfit_sex <- summary(fit_sex)  # graph the estimated distributed lag functions for each group plot(sfit_sex)   # can save plot as an object and modify with ggplot2 library(ggplot2) plt <- plot(sfit_sex) plt + ggtitle("My plot with BDLIM") +  ylab("Estimated expected difference in\nBWGAZ per 1 ug/m3 increase in exposure")   # the summary file has the data to make this plot head(sfit_sex$dlfun) #>   group time          mean        median          sd         q2.5       q97.5 #> 1     F    1 -2.606126e-04 -8.077639e-05 0.006987485 -0.014968317 0.014590886 #> 2     F    2 -8.520968e-05 -1.414316e-05 0.005683340 -0.011941546 0.011753364 #> 3     F    3  9.032047e-05  3.722980e-05 0.004528555 -0.009038281 0.009742242 #> 4     F    4  2.661052e-04  6.981623e-05 0.003637270 -0.007095297 0.008062532 #> 5     F    5  4.422717e-04  7.942015e-05 0.003144049 -0.005942947 0.007497169 #> 6     F    6  6.189474e-04  1.503979e-04 0.003097666 -0.005247367 0.007777040 #>   pr_gr0 #> 1 0.4880 #> 2 0.4976 #> 3 0.5076 #> 4 0.5172 #> 5 0.5344 #> 6 0.5628

title: Simulated Birth Data — simulated_birth_data_bdlim
code: simulated_birth_data_bdlim

title: Simulated Birth Data — simulated_birth_data_bdlim
text: data frame 1000 rows (observations) 51 variables: bwgaz Outcome used. Simulated birth weight gestational age z-score. pm25_1 -- pm25_37 Exposure used. Weekly average exposure PM2.5 first 37 weeks gestations.

title: Simulated Birth Data — simulated_birth_data_c1
text: dataset containing simulated birth data examples bdlim. Add outcome covariate data simulated. exposure data real exposure data. Therefore, realistic correlation structure. exposures consistent date conception variables.

title: Simulated Birth Data — simulated_birth_data_c1
code: simulated_birth_data_c1

title: Simulated Birth Data — simulated_birth_data_c1
text: data frame 1000 rows (observations) 51 variables: bwgaz Outcome used. Simulated birth weight gestational age z-score. ChildSex Binary sex child. MomAge Continuous age years. GestAge Continuous estimated gestational age birth weeks. MomHeightIn Continuous maternal height inches. MomPriorWeightLbs Continuous mothers pre-pregnancy weight pounds. MomPriorBMI Continuous mothers pre-pregnancy BMI. race Categorical race. Hispanic Binary indicator Hispanic. MomEdu Categorical maternal heighest educational attainment. SmkAny Binary indicator smoking pregnancy. Marital Categorical maternal marital status. Income Categorical income. EstDateConcept Estimated date conception. EstMonthConcept Estimated month conception. EstYearConcept Estimated year conception. pm25_1 Exposure used. Weekly average exposure PM2.5 week 1 gestation. pm25_2 Exposure used. code: # run BDLIM with modification by ChildSex fit_sex <- bdlim4(   y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz,   exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,paste0("pm25_",1:37)],   covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,c("MomPriorBMI","MomAge","race","Hispanic",                                       "EstMonthConcept","EstYearConcept")],   group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),   df = 5,   nits = 5000,   parallel = FALSE ) #> fitting bw #> fitting b #> fitting w #> fitting n #> postprocessingpostprocessing  #summarize results summary(fit_sex) #>  #> Call: #> bdlim4(y = simulated_birth_data_c1$bwgaz, exposure = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     paste0("pm25_", 1:37)], covars = simulated_birth_data_c1[,  #>     c("MomPriorBMI", "MomAge", "race", "Hispanic", "EstMonthConcept",  #>         "EstYearConcept")], group = as.factor(simulated_birth_data_c1$ChildSex),  #>     df = 5, nits = 5000, parallel = FALSE) #>  #>  #> Model fit statistics: #>   *bw*      b      w      n  #> 0.5388 0.4612 0.0000 0.0000  #>  #>  #> Estimated cumulative effects: #>  group        mean       median         sd        q2.5      q97.5 pr_gr0 #>      F  0.01187347  0.003653079 0.05762978 -0.09725315  0.1512315 0.5616 #>      M -0.65683208 -0.654748819 0.08948275 -0.83761976 -0.4863330 0.0000 #>  #>  #> Estimated covariate regression coefficients: #>                   name         mean       median          sd          q2.5 #>  interceptnames_groups -0.981686506 -0.854420167 6.392724579 -13.476859845 #>  interceptnames_groups  0.664621725  0.692722434 6.404494949 -12.013671074 #>            MomPriorBMI -0.054165930 -0.054150469 0.003103011  -0.060161692 #>                 MomAge -0.001598150 -0.001599771 0.003061075  -0.007625413 #>            raceAsianPI  0.162480445  0.162286973 0.235976204  -0.309126925 #>              raceBlack  0.042624411  0.043652178 0.244448918  -0.442064119 #>              racewhite  0.108428431  0.108382826 0.231836853  -0.354523308 #>    HispanicNonHispanic  0.255497198  0.256258360 0.039396170   0.178093607 #>        EstMonthConcept  0.037220717  0.037353048 0.005256329   0.026862616 #>         EstYearConcept  0.001434604  0.001410768 0.003178737  -0.004812150 #>         q97.5 pr_gr0 #>  11.733985161 0.4440 #>  13.353450573 0.5460 #>  -0.048026623 0.0000 #>   0.004437767 0.2980 #>   0.614934658 0.7640 #>   0.505707017 0.5684 #>   0.547496919 0.6792 #>   0.331047945 1.0000 #>   0.047372740 1.0000 #>   0.007724138 0.6744 #>  #>  #> BDLIM fit on 1000 observations. Estimated residual standard deviation is 0.562 (0.537,0.587). WAIC is 1696.97. #>  #> Use `plot(); for the summary.bdlim4 object to view estimated distributed lag functions. The `dlfun' object in the summary object contains estimates of the lag functions.  # obtain estimates of the distributed lag function # these are note displayed when printed but available for use sfit_sex <- summary(fit_sex) head(sfit_sex$dlfun) #>   group time          mean        median          sd         q2.5       q97.5 #> 1     F    1 -4.581809e-04 -1.171578e-04 0.006715409 -0.015408857 0.013650639 #> 2     F    2 -2.590265e-04 -6.765207e-05 0.005478182 -0.012122374 0.011286335 #> 3     F    3 -6.015346e-05 -2.305763e-06 0.004389197 -0.009647235 0.009404473 #> 4     F    4  1.381569e-04  3.675251e-05 0.003557869 -0.007328891 0.007667433 #> 5     F    5  3.356231e-04  9.610602e-05 0.003107765 -0.006186174 0.007132784 #> 6     F    6  5.319640e-04  1.727777e-04 0.003075892 -0.005471435 0.007575251 #>   pr_gr0 #> 1 0.4764 #> 2 0.4780 #> 3 0.4976 #> 4 0.5160 #> 5 0.5380 #> 6 0.5596  # can summarize with a specific model sfit_hisp_n <- summary(fit_sex, model="n") # no modification sfit_hisp_b <- summary(fit_sex, model="b") # subgroup-specific effects (beta) sfit_hisp_w <- summary(fit_sex, model="w") # subgroup-specific weight function sfit_hisp_bw <- summary(fit_sex, model="bw") # both subgroup-specific
